comments.commentBody:
I loved the quote that Nicklaus chose golf because it didn't require teamwork!. It's a great analogy to the GOP's reliance on the foolish and disingenuous "you built it" mantra. That attitude reminds one of an eighth grader's surly efforts to bolster a troubled sense of self-worth.

(With apologies to most eighth graders!)
I had not heard that one about the water heater, but it certainly reminds me of the money he is hiding away from the country he supposedly wants to help.   Cold showers for everyone!
Republican turnout will be low because nobody likes to vote for a loser.

Jack Nicklaus isn't legend enough to convince many more than those committed GOP voters to go against their own self-interest. Romney is his own worst witness in and out of quiet rooms. If most people don't have a very clear sense of where they stand in Romney's pie chart, they certainly will by mid-October. That secret tape in Florida is confirmation that everything we've ever suspected about Romney is true, and then some. It also doesn't help when Mrs. Romney goes on Leno and calls her husband "cheap," with so much glee and then goes on to describe, in very embarrassing details, just how miserly and devious her husband is in turning off the water heater before leaving the house, pretending to turn it back on after getting home and, when asked about it, saying that cold showers aren't that bad.

These are the kinds of small things that stick in people's mind. It's not hard to extrapolate from there that things like no more food stamps, healthcare, education, infrastructure aren't that bad, either.

I suspect that when all is said and done, Republican turnout will be relatively low precisely because of the sum total of these revelations and how well people relate to them.

"skewed polls" So Mr. Silver averages the polls. It's not a conspiracy, really

"poll weighting"
This is scientific process with good tools to account for polling discrepancies, namely, reliable (trustworthy) organizations will offer transparency how this effect is accommodated in their results. The fact is that the weighting of D/R/I is situational and time dependent can not be concretely identified like factors of race, income, etc.

"The United States is the real basket case in this area, and it's not just because this is an election year -- our entire political system is broken"

Yes. It gets worse, more obvious, with each election cycle.

1- Those cities dedicated to one industry lack diversification.  If something happens to depress the demand for that industry's exports, the city will experience huge unemployment, poverty and social unrest. You are right that the same cannot be said for US cities, though the auto industry's domination of Detroit is a pretty good example.  You should visit Detroit someday! :)

2- The cities being developed create jobs and profits, during the development phase.  I'm sure they are amazing, just as you say.  But politicians around the world frequently invest in capital projects that are not feasible in a business sense ... because the motive for developing them may be political and therefore not focused on producing value for consumers from each dollar of cost.  The upshot is that the bigger these projects are, the greater the 'deadweight loss' of wasted resources. You'll know it when you see it.

You say that on a macro level, China will be just fine.  You have no way of knowing that. (Neither does anyone.)  Bubbles burst and financial panics begin in the least expected places, and spread faster than one can imagine.  But I hope your dream comes true.  It would be bad not only China, but for the entire world if things turn out as suggested by the article.

The Chinese people have produced an economic miracle! You have come very far in 30 years.

However, widely shared information, a reliable legal system and an efficient financial system must provide a foundation for sustained economic growth.  Economic growth without that foundation may not be sustainable.  I hope the next generation of leaders focus their energies on these elements of China's 'infrastructure.'

If China's wages double every five years from their current $0.70/hr, then it will take over 25 years for them to reach our poverty level!

This is not going to happen, because the economies of the US and Europe will be destroyed by china's aggressive economic policies long before this comes about. Then the lack of Chinese exports will kill their economy. It is not sustainable and it never was.
Impressive display. That 6th grade education was not wasted.
Yes, it is always the same basic process ... but the scale is different.  Constitutional protection of the rights of citizens keeps it in check.

I liked the theme, even though it has been done before. Do I remember the one from 11 years ago? Of course. Doesn’t everyone?

I was less impressed with the fill. The cluing was too tedious with cross references (besides the theme clues), of which I hate to see more than one in a 15x15.

I didn’t like FEW, MEW, NEW, TIE TOY, OHSO after yesterday's OHNO, and COO after only two days. We also had OCTOPI a few days ago. I would have preferred the Greek island for IOS and “ORA pro nobis” instead of the fill-in-the-blanks OR A.

I liked to see Peggy NOONAN and YOYOMA, but LEONID Brezhnev much less so. I also liked the ELUSIVE Orion NEBULA whose life is counted in CATYEARS, and DARE I SAY, the SCOTSMAN ONPAROLE playing a BASS SOLO as PENANCE. And GLACIERs are always cool.

Here LEONID Kogan, the great Russian violinist plays Niccolo Paganini’s "La Campanella":

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lWaOnqmtr9U

Good night!

Josh Mandel is not involved with throwing the election to Romney. He is running for the Senate, a 30 something career politician who weeks after being elected as state treasurer, and having promised to fill out the complete term if elected, set out to run for the Senate.

John Husted is the Ohio Secretary of State, who is the point man in Ohio's efforts to make voting easy for Republicans and difficult for Democratic leaning groups.

It does make one feel important driving through other electorally irrelevant states with a Obama 2012 bumper sticker on the back of my car.

Please remember, however, that as one of the last states to have primaries, part of our apathy is a result of the rest of the nation already winnowing down the list of acceptable, real candidates to the bare minimum before we even get a chance. We are always stuck with the guys the rest of you choose. The more interesting, risk taking early candidates are long gone before we get a shot at voting for them.

To Jim S:

I suspect you might know some Republicans in Cleveland; and some might even be friends. I'm having some bumper stickers printed up, and they're welcome to some:

"Vote early, vote often and vote Republican". Beats the Obama 2012 stickers all to heck.

Voters in Ohio deserve medals for all they must endure. It is not the ads, but rather their own officials trying to steal the election that are the obstacles. Josh Mandel did everything in his power to throw the election to Romney. It was shocking and embarrassing.

That said, I resent deeply the fact that because of the electoral college system Ohio, Florida and other "swing state" voters end up determining the election for the rest of us. It makes one wonder why we even bother. The candidates have the election gamed down to the precinct level. It is marketing on an almost invasive scale that grants power often to the least informed voters. I wish I could believe that that small sliver of "undecided" voters were undecided because they had really done their homework and found the candidates roughly equal. Interviews on PBS and other outlets with these voters showed how shallow and uninformed they could be. Saturday Night Live parodied them and with good reason. This cheapens the election and fosters the worst kind of political behavior--pandering!

I agree completely. It wasn't too bad when our local baseball stadium was called Pacific Bell Park, it sorta referenced a certain ocean we like!

But AT&T Park? What? This giving alphabet soup names to sports stadiums just drives me nuts.

I agree completely. It wasn't too bad when our local baseball stadium was called Pacific Bell Park, it sorta referenced a certain ocean we like!

But AT&T Park? What? This giving alphabet soup names to sports stadiums just drives me nuts.

Do you even know what the disputed issues are, or do you just assume because the owners are rich that they are wrong and evil and the refs are righteous and angelic. Get real. You expect the owners to have to negotiate with a dozen different unions and then wonder why ticket prices go up. Do you think the refs should be allowed to remain part time, receive enormous compensation for roughly 20 days of work per year, earn a full pension, deny the league the ability to train back up refs, etc.
The replacement refs are obviously willing to do the job for much less and by next year would be just as good as the original refs. That's how the free market works and your ticket prices stay down.

Do you even know what the disputed issues are, or do you just assume because the owners are rich that they are wrong and evil and the refs are righteous and angelic. Get real. You expect the owners to have to negotiate with a dozen different unions and then wonder why ticket prices go up. Do you think the refs should be allowed to remain part time, receive enormous compensation for roughly 20 days of work per year, earn a full pension, deny the league the ability to train back up refs, etc.
The replacement refs are obviously willing to do the job for much less and by next year would be just as good as the original refs. That's how the free market works and your ticket prices stay down.

[You meant LESS angry.]

And it would eliminate what I believe must be one of the worst "customer service" jobs anywhere. The insurance company employee who has to field the calls from insureds. Must be very depressing work.

The public option where we all use one system instead of 4,000 different plans would make everyones lives better with the exception of large health insurance senior management.

It would be better for businesses, when they no longer have to worry about health insurance for employees or how to factor that overhead into the price of their products.

It would make hospitals and doctor's offices more productive.

It would make the country healthier.

And I would go to bed angry tonight.

"How stupid and naive does Ursey think we fans are?"

Evidently, a lot. Go Payton Manning! Super Bowl!

"How stupid and naive does Ursey think we fans are?"

Evidently, a lot. Go Payton Manning! Super Bowl!

Anyone have an actual reason for siding with the refs other than the fact that the owners are rich? Does anyone here even know some of the ridiculous demands of the refs, who by the way, are mostly very well off. Is it that any time at least 10 people get together, call themselves a union, and hold their breaths like babies until they get what they want they are somehow automatically noble. Grow up. This is a fair negotiation between employers and employees.
If there is no Lockout (Owners) or Walkout (union) there is no incentive to settle the differences.
Refs were locked out.  Owners wanted to change the status quo.  A case of trying to be penny-wise and pound foolish.

Refs are mostly well off? Many officials lose any full-time job they have because they are committed to a near 40 hr work week as an NFL official. There are 122 NFL refs, not 10.
These officials are able to do what no one else can do. It isn't exactly like working on an old-fashioned auto assembly line...where a person could be replaced in a minute's notice.
I know pro officials personally and they are very good at their jobs. Hold their breath like babies? How insulting to another person's profession!

And what is fair about negotiations between billionaire owners and ANYONE!

Anyone have an actual reason for siding with the refs other than the fact that the owners are rich? Does anyone here even know some of the ridiculous demands of the refs, who by the way, are mostly very well off. Is it that any time at least 10 people get together, call themselves a union, and hold their breaths like babies until they get what they want they are somehow automatically noble. Grow up. This is a fair negotiation between employers and employees.
Hey that's 47% of America you're talking about.
It was listed as red because that map was not designed to project, but instead to present a picture of a Romney-wins-without-Ohio scenario.
I actually think the numbers are flipped around, right?  Bush won reelection with a 2.5% margin, I think.
Why conservative?  Doesn't the Daily Beast skew liberal?
Perhaps just from the way it was programmed. Since loops usually start at zero, if the upper limit was 25,000 and it was coded to be inclusive, then it'll end up with 25,001 simulation runs.

Probably unassailable. Take a look at your favorite election map tool; I'll use the one at CNN. Start from the default map and click Florida to blue, and all that's needed for Obama is any remaining yellow state. Then use the pulldown menu and start from the 2004 result, but flip Florida to blue: another Obama win. Or start from the 2008 result and flip Florida to red: Obama still wins (Florida is must-win for Romney, not for Obama). Start from Castellano's partisan forecast, and flip Florida blue, and again Obama clinches it. Start from Carville's partisan map, and, well, Obama's already got it, with or without Florida.

You'd have to start from very non-mainstream assignments of states, to find a way for Romney to win without Florida.
